prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We only require a photometric point at 350GHz, therefore we request continuum observations, in the low resolution correlator mode (Time Division Mode) with the bandwidth set at the standard 7.5GHz.

This host galaxy can be considered to be a point source. To resolve it against other field sources we require an angular resolution of 1 arcsec. Since this object is a point source, there are no large scale components to resolve, therefore we set the largest angular scale to be 0.0.

Our science goal is to measure the flux density during the Rayleigh-Jeans part of the host galaxy spectrum. In order to do this we require one ALMA band 7 data point. At an observed frequency of 350GHz, we expect a flux of about 150uJy. In order to secure a 5 sigma detection, we therefore require a sensitivity of 30.0uJy

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Long gamma-ray bursts (LGRBs), are the brightest transient events in the Universe. This, combined with their wide range in redshift and the fact that they are associated with the collapse of massive, metal poor stars, establishes LGRBs as powerful probes of cosmic star formation back to the early Universe. Here we propose 31 hours of ALMA band 7 for targeted observations of 25 LGRB host galaxies in the z=3-7 range, what we refer to as the `star-formation rate (SFR) desert' because the exact shape of the cosmic star-formation history is not known. Our aim is to calculate star-formation rates for these galaxies and use them to trace the cosmic star-formation history at z=3-7. There are only a handful of estimated SFRs for GRB host galaxies in that epoch, the vast majority of which are UV/optically derived where dust extinction is a hindering factor. z=3-7 is the epoch of early star-formation and hence understanding the shape and evolution of the star-formation rate density in that redshift range will enable us to understand the progression between the epoch of re-ionisation and the present-day Universe.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: University College London, London, University of
University College London, London, University of
